video.title: Learn HTML5 and CSS3 From Scratch - Full Course
video.description:
HTML and CSS are essential skills to have for a career in web development.

In this course we will cover both languages from the scratch and by the end of the course you will be creating your own projects.

topLevelComment.author: Ray Silva
topLevelComment.text:
Just for clarity's sake, there's a quick mention of access to the course resources at 43:07-08 that starting with this video you can access the code from the zip file of the course resources. 

Be aware that is not accessible from here at all. You must go to his Udemy course. There you will find that the code is not accessible unless you have bought the course. It is not very expensive. Often you may even get it on sale for  $9.99, but is is not free. There is no github repo listed in this course's resources. You may be confused. 

The video at that point in this lecture is NOT from this "course." It is from the Udemy course. None of the resource files he mentions are free.

topLevelComment.author: Devon Martin
topLevelComment.text:
At 4:45:25, you say that Hex gives more color choices than rgb, but that is false. They represent the exact same data as each other, just in different formats.

RGB goes from values of 0 to 255.
FF in hex is 255.

This is the reason why inline css is the most powerful - because it will always be the last one.

topLevelComment.author: Code Treasury
topLevelComment.text:
My Opinion After Watching & Applying.

First Time: 
Watch the whole video just seeing the concepts without pausing the video. In the process you will still learn much.

Second Time:
Watch and practice at the same time. You will be more confident as you already know how things are gonna come and how they will work.

Mindset:
Consider this not 11.3 hours long video that you are compelled to watch, rather 11.30 hours short hack that will build your career.

topLevelComment.author: Rob DeVore
topLevelComment.text:
Out of the many HTML+CSS tutorials I've watched, this has been BY FAR the most in-depth tutorial, while also allowing for easy comprehension. It's astonishing to me that this is free. 

11 hours is nothing in the grand scheme of things. I put the course on 1.25x speed and finished it within a 2 day span. My level of understanding of HTML and CSS is now 100x what it used to be when I was trying other courses out. I'm going to hone my skills and develop some simple webpages now, and hopefully move onto some Javascript courses. 

Very grateful to you sir, for the wonderful experience.

topLevelComment.author: Xavier Xavier
topLevelComment.text:
This is the video I started with about a year ago when I was trying to learn to code. Just landed my first programming job yesterday.

For those who wanted to know more about my journey:

I started teaching myself web dev while in school for computer science a few weeks before my second semester of college. Over the next like 6 months, I kept learning and making projects. I taught myself in this order: HTML, CSS, JS, React, Node using Express.js, then PostgreSQL. 

Before I started teaching myself, the only experience I had with programming was an intro to programming class in college where we learned the fundamentals of programming using Java. I really didn’t do much programming in school during my first year of college. Other than that, I learned everything else about programming through YouTube videos. I thought learning web dev could help me build my resume and get some internships. I wasn’t planning on applying to jobs while I was still in school at first.

After that, i kinda stopped programming outside of school for a while because tbh i kinda got a little burnt out. 

A few months later, two weeks before the second semester of my sophomore year, I started applying to part-time remote web dev jobs because I didn’t get any internships. Eventually, I got accepted into a job making $18 an hour working part-time, which isn’t a huuuge amount for a web dev job, but great money for a broke college student.

I work in front-end. My job only really requires me to use HTML, CSS, and JS. I work with a small team making educational games on the web for K-12 students.

The grind really sucked, but I guess it paid off in the end? I just remember just studying and coding every day for hours until my brain hurt. One of the hardest things I’ve done. It sucked big time. Just glad that grind is over.

topLevelComment.author: enikyne
topLevelComment.text:
Pray for me folks... I am entering this career path as a not so tech-savvy person. For those in my shoes, here's some encouragement. Taking notes, following along, and understanding errors i make, it took me almost a whole month to finish this course! Full time physical job and a supportive wife, plus other time consuming life duties I covered 30 minutes of content a day. I never thought i'd understand anything but with faith and consistency, we can do all things :)  

Also, i use to type like a turtle with my neck hunched down at the keyboard but i forced myself to take my time following along with proper typing finger form(tutorials!) I believe in perfecting form will make the long run a whole lot better for anyone.
On to the next part, whichever it is xD God bless y'all and hang in there!

topLevelComment.author: Gediminas Kulakauskas
topLevelComment.text: Just to let people know about copying Image links from the web- instead of right clicking on the image and then copying the image link address, what you can do is right click on the image ---> open the image in a new tab ----> copy the link that you see displayed in the browser link box. This way, it's very likely that the link will be more condensed and will point straight to the source instead of the Google's algorithm which provides these links that are soooooooooooo long.

topLevelComment.author: Mohammad Abdelrahman
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you for the video, but just a slight correction about colors 

There is zero difference between RGB & HEX in terms of the "number" of colors. They're just two different ways to represent colors. 

The difference between RGB/HEX ... and HSL comes in things related to animations because it's much easier to work with RGB than HEX

Also there's the matter of printers as well, vector art, etc.... It's a big topic even for those who are specialized in colors. But in short, for a webdesinger, 99% of the time both RGB and HEX are the same. Just use whatever is easier for you.... both of them have the same level of "difficulty"

topLevelComment.author: aerdon085
topLevelComment.text:
Done! I started on June 7 and finished on August 9. The total days I studied through this course was 19 days. All the gaps are days wherein I tried and applied what I've learned by developing a website for my father's business. Now, I'm not sure I have EVERYTHING he just said on the top of my head, but I kept a note through which I could refer to PLUS all the resources he recommended. Thanks so much!

What I've heard is that Javascript should be next after this. I've also been told to go for PHP. I plan to attain "fluency" in web development, then move on to C++ or Python or whatever. Still not sure, but I'll worry about software development when I get there.

In any case, if people wouldn't mind, give this comment a like so I could--and everyone else--keep track of those who have finished the course. Comment your journey and your destination :D my ultimate goal is to be a game developer!

topLevelComment.text: 4:45 correction HEX and RGB values are the same, hex stores 16 values in one place ranging from 0 to F, and each red green and blue has 2 digits of hex #RRGGBB, in RGB the values range from 0 to 255 that is 256 values in total. so if we multiply the two possible digits for RR as 16*16 it ends up to 256 that is the maximum value to red in RGB numbers. similarly to green and blue.

replies.author: Succubus
replies.text:
You could buy the course, yes. It is worth it for sure. But I highly recommend you to buy either "The Web Developer Bootcamp 2021 by colt steele" or "The Complete 2021 Web Development Bootcamp by Dr. Angela yu".
These are the top tier on udemy and either are good but I like Angela way of teaching a bit more. both are around 60 hours, so if you can buy both you will be a very good dev. Wait for sales you can get pretty cheap idk how much since I don't use EUR or USD currency but It should be less than 10$.
Or you could just do the Freecodecamp course in the website, which is everything you need, but those two I listed will make go even further in your career.
Since I have the time I intend to do all 3 which should take me about 8-9 months. Probably less since I'm already familiar with python and I have that as a advantage to cut a lot time learning things that are similar to what learned with it. (also to learn python took me about 5 months)

topLevelComment.author: Syed Sirajul Islam Anik
topLevelComment.text:
I have finished the 1 hr and 15 minutes and didn't find him giving any clue about the path. Just in case you're looking for.
- The `/` forward slash means the root of the path. If it's the server, as he ran the `127.0.0.1:5500`, then `/udemy.png` means it's in the root of the `html` directory.
- If you're browsing through the file system, your URL is like`file:///path/to/your/index.html`, then `/` will mean the root directory. And your files will not be available in that path.
- In both the above cases for server or file system, the `./` or `../` will work seamlessly. 

Hope it helps.

- Reminder -
Last touch:  (10:06:00)

replies.author: Liz Q
replies.text: Done!

replies.author: Liz Q
replies.text:
06:58:27 - the browser will respect margin and padding of block, but not of inline. So you can directly change the link inside the unorderlist instead... OR better option is use Inline-block
07:08:00 - border box attribute limits the padding in side the box-1. Use global selector for negating the default browsing style
08:06:51 - short syntax for background attributes
08:35:00 - Needs an ancestor that is relative to work with the absolute value
media queries - min-width= starting from, max-width= up to, recent max-width will override smaller values before it. Z-index works on relative and absolute but not on fixed
(09:06:04) ::Before And ::After Pseudo Elements (useful for animation)

replies.author: Liz Q
replies.text:
note: name attribute will make the radio button group together, rgba for opacity,
4:24:00 - Last Rule, Specificity, Universal Selector (haven't learned before)
somewhere in between - . in css is equivalent to class in html
5:07:00 - relative and absolute (only for text em [relative], px[absolute]. not really the div block setting...) EM respects the parent, REM respects root (html)
I finished HTML and exercise
05:29:07 - Calc Function (navbar and hero banner) dont forget space before and after operator
06:02:21 - Text Decoration for removing link's underline
06:12:39 - up, right, down, left
6:12:53 - combining all border (width style color)
6:34:00 - outline and it's offset ( your can style buttons where outline can get inside, whereas margin cannot)

replies.author: Liz Q
replies.text: External Links, Internal Links, Links Within Page

replies.author: Liz Q
replies.text:
1:14:15 - Multiple Path Options:
note: img src attribute (no forward slash), with forward slash (/), one dot forward slash (./) and with 2 dot forward slash (../)

topLevelComment.author: xx03 _p
topLevelComment.text: 11 hours to learn HTML and CSS is way OVERKILL! Plus It might not be a good idea for a beginner to spend that many hours on the subject. HTML and CSS seem easy at glance but the learning curve gets stiff VERY quick! My advice for you (if you’re a beginner). You don't need to know everything to start working with markup languages. Learn the fundamentals first then master to fundamentals finally increment your knowledge as you work on your projects over time. This is the exact implicit reason why so many people fail to learn web development. It's like you’re trying to teach English by telling people to go the entire dictionary! Just not a good idea!

topLevelComment.author: A A
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you very much for sharing your expertise and knowledge in this tutorial. It is awesome to have this content for free and learn more about html and css.

However, I feel like I REALLY I have to point out annoying little habit you have with the spoken English language:

"We will going to do this and we will going to do that" and "It will gonna be done installing" is incorrect. Please use the verb "to be" instead of the adverb "to will". In other words, in English we say  "We ARE going to do this and we ARE going to do that..." and "It IS gonna be done installing". Thanks.

topLevelComment.author: Juanjozo
topLevelComment.text:
Excelent tutorial! Just a quick note for 3:41:28.
The style of h1 doesn't get overwritten by the internal style element in the html file because it is "stronger", but because of the order in which instructions are passed (first the external css file source is assigned, and then the internal style element gets declared).
For instance, if one were to put the internal style element before the assignment of the external css file, then the external css settings would take over (since they are the last to be executed).

Writing this review after watching and working out this full video:
PROS:
         * One of the best lecturers i have ever met
         * His ideology is that he will explain the core concept behind every aspects and components
         * He wont confuse one aspect with another - instead he will teach every concepts individually
            ( Hence total 11 hrs - worth it )
CONS:
         * This is not Full Course as it illustrates - the total course length is 48.5 hours and its a udemy course
         * Flex box and the grid wont be covered in this 11 hrs tutorial - ( which will be covered in his udemy course )
         * There will be no major project - creation involved in this tutorial - it will be there in udemy

topLevelComment.author: 15.168 Tarif Hossain
topLevelComment.text: Hi, just out of curiosity... Why should anyone learn HTML CSS, specially when you can create a beautiful website using only WordPress? With the "Elementor Pro" it's so easy to design a beautiful website. I mean I don't want provoke anybody. I just want to know why? Also in Fiverr, there's a lot of work for WordPress developers whereas I don't see many people asking for static HTML CSS developer. It makes sense because the clients wouldn't just want to be left off with a design that he cannot change. I mean with static HTML CSS, if a client isn't familiar with it, even to change a simple image, he'd have to hire somebody. But with WordPress, he can do it himself. It's very easy for the clients to manage a WordPress and because it has a good demand, WordPress developers can make more money whereas static HTML CSS developers can't. So why should people invest his time into learning HTML CSS which doesn't guarantee his income?

topLevelComment.author: Iced Alpha
topLevelComment.text: I was following, cause I really want to learn this, but when i downloaded Live Server,  i didn't get a Reload button.  So..... I'm stuck.  I played around with it and discovered that if you Right Click on it, it'll ask you if you want to download another version (one of the options it gives) hit YES. Then it'll give you those options (choose the one that is just below the one marked Current), then you'll get the reload button. Then it'll ask if toy want to upgrade to the latest version ( which is the current version) say Yes. Then we're all caught up. It Was Annoying.

topLevelComment.author: The horrible story of a man whose name was too lon
topLevelComment.text: "Now what in the world is HTML? HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, and what this mumbo jumbo gibberish means is that HTML is not a programming language, it is in fact a markup language" Yeah but that sentence does not explain what HTML means though ... Hyper text means links basically(text that takes you to other text), and markup means describing or annotating text with other text(tags in this case), so called meta information. So HTML is a way to describe information that also links to other information.

topLevelComment.author: Randy Miller
topLevelComment.text: i completed this a couple days ago. Now I'm taking another course of his on Skillshare that is 35  hours long. This is the best most complete course I've had. I've really turned a corner, after a year of frustration. I recommend this course! John keeps all examples to their essence. You never are making a tedious app with unimportant topics coming up, like other classes. Each concept is taught relatively isolated, and you can really see what is going on specifically. ALSO, John spends A LOT of time on how to use the program to code efficiently. It was all new to me. Really using Emmet, etc. A game changer. Thanks John!

replies.author: Whiny Twat
replies.text:
I was about to comment about it when I came across this. 
To the students: Hex and RGB give you EXACTLY the same amount of options i.e. 256 for each 'broad' shade on the color spectrum (red, green, and blue) , the only difference is that each shade is expressed differently. In RGB you have one number for each shade for a total of 256 (0-255). In the Hex you have two digits for each shade where each digit can take a value from 0-15 (0-9, then abcdef representing 10, 11..., 15), putting the total options for each shade at 256 (16*16).  To summarize, you have 256 options for each primary color.
